title-group.article-title: Interest Rate Risk of Stock Prices in Nigeria
title-group.subtitle: Empirical Test of the Duration and Convexity Model

contrib-group.aff: Raphael I. Udegbunam, Department of Economics & Statistics, University of Benin, Benin City, Nigeria. E-mail: rudegbunam2002@yahoo.com
Hassan E. Oaikhenan, Department of Economics & Statistics, University of Benin, Benin City, Nigeria. E-mail: hassanoaikhenan@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 Institute of Financial Management and Research
permissions.copyright-holder: Institute of Financial Management and Research

abstract.p: The article empirically examines the response of stock prices in the Nigerian Stock Market to interest rate risk, using the Duration and Convexity model. A simple non-linear stock price model that incorporates measure of interest rate duration and convexity and a vector containing a battery of other control variables is specified and estimated using annual secondary data that covered the 1981–2006 sample period. The empirical results largely corroborate the hypothesis of interest rate sensitivity of stock prices in the Nigerian Stock Market. Specifically, we find both measures of interest rate duration and convexity to exert strong but opposite effects on stock prices in Nigeria. The empirical evidence shows that the net effect of interest rate changes on stock prices is negative, an indication that stock prices fall with increases in stock risk. The results provide empirical support for the duration and convexity hypothesis of the existence of a non-linear relationship between interest rate risk and stock prices in Nigeria.
